description: Sybaris was an ancient city of Magna Graecia founded as an Achaean colony as early as 720 BCE on a plain that was drained by both the Crati and Sybaris rivers. Greeks from Kroton destroyed Sybaris ca. 510 BCE. Following this destruction, two successive cities, Thurii and Copia, respectively, were established on the same site. This topic is of particular interest to ancient authors, at least 70 of whom mention it.
details:
The Barrington Atlas Directory notes: Sibari/Copia.

Froelich Rainey (1969) offers a succinct summary of the settlement phases. Following the destruction of Sybaris ca. 510 BCE, there was a brief re-establishment of the city, but that, too, was razed. Athenians were encouraged to establish Thurii "near" the site of Sybaris in the fifth century BCE, a site famously planned by Hippodamos of Miletus. Lucanians then sacked Thurii ca. 390 BCE. The Roman Republic established a garrison at the site in 282 BCE. The ancient settlement lived until it was abandoned in the ninth century.
